sentences.sentence: TikTok recognized the Ukrainian campaign #NOMOREGRINGE as an impactful and influential project.
Officially, 15 most popular TikTokers of Ukraine, 15 opinion leaders from business, public sector, television, and more joined the campaign.
They chose the theme of their video from a collection of more than a hundred common stereotypes.
Their bias-eliminating videos are available on TikTok, Instagram and Facebook, with the official hashtags of the #GRINGE, #NOMOREGRINGE campaign.
The #NOMOREGRINGE hashtag is a neologism originating from the slang word Cringe, a feeling of embarrassment and shame, and the letter "G" from the English word "gender".
Gringe is a shame and embarrassment that you feel when someone applies gender stereotypes or voices them.

The very idea of implementing the project arose after a survey of 175 teenagers aged 13-19 years from 25 cities of Ukraine, that was conducted within the framework of the program "EU for Gender Equality: Together Against Gender Stereotypes and Gender-Based Violence", with the support of the EU in conjunction with UN Women and UNFPA.

66.3% of them experienced gender bias towards themselves, 47.3% faced discrimination in various forms, while 53% of Ukrainian teenagers would like to learn more about gender equality issues so to recognize and struggle with gender stereotypes.
"Deep seated discriminatory norms, stereotypes and prejudice remain pervasive, thus holding back women and girls from realizing their rights.
We all learn very early on the expectations and limitations of our gender roles, and they are deeply embedded in our social, political and economic structures.
Definitely the changes will happen, not overnight, but incrementally and steadily", - comments Erika Kvapilova, UN Women Ukraine Country Representative.
The problem of stereotypes in society is much deeper than individual reactions in response to societal pressure.
"A woman has no place in business or IT", "Didn't fight - not a man",

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

text: TikTok recognized the Ukrainian campaign #NOMOREGRINGE as an impactful and influential project. Officially, 15 most popular TikTokers of Ukraine, 15 opinion leaders from business, public sector, television, and more joined the campaign. They chose the theme of their video from a collection of more than a hundred common stereotypes. Their bias-eliminating videos are available on TikTok, Instagram and Facebook, with the official hashtags of the #GRINGE, #NOMOREGRINGE campaign. The #NOMOREGRINGE hashtag is a neologism originating from the slang word Cringe, a feeling of embarrassment and shame, and the letter "G" from the English word "gender". Gringe is a shame and embarrassment that you feel when someone applies gender stereotypes or voices them. The very idea of implementing the project arose after a survey of 175 teenagers aged 13-19 years from 25 cities of Ukraine, that was conducted within the framework of the program "EU for Gender Equality: Together Against Gender Stereotypes and Gender-Based Violence", with the support of the EU in conjunction with UN Women and UNFPA. 66.3% of them experienced gender bias towards themselves, 47.3% faced discrimination in various forms, while 53% of Ukrainian teenagers would like to learn more about gender equality issues so to recognize and struggle with gender stereotypes. "Deep seated discriminatory norms, stereotypes and prejudice remain pervasive, thus holding back women and girls from realizing their rights. We all learn very early on the expectations and limitations of our gender roles, and they are deeply embedded in our social, political and economic structures. Definitely the changes will happen, not overnight, but incrementally and steadily", – comments Erika Kvapilova, UN Women Ukraine Country Representative. The problem of stereotypes in society is much deeper than individual reactions in response to societal pressure. "A woman has no place in business or IT", "Didn't fight - not a man",
